content:
PresentationSource Class

In this Article

Provides an abstract base for classes that present content from another technology as part of an interoperation scenario. In addition, this class provides static methods for working with these sources, as well as the basic visual-layer presentation architecture.

Syntax

Declaration

public abstract class PresentationSource : System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherObject

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherObject
  • PresentationSource

Gets the visual target for the visuals being presented in the source.

Returns a list of sources.

When overridden in a derived class, gets a value that declares whether the object is disposed.

When overridden in a derived class, gets or sets the root visual being presented in the source.

Adds a PresentationSource derived class instance to the list of known presentation sources.

Adds a handler for the SourceChanged event to the provided element.

Sets the list of listeners for the ContentRendered event to null.

Returns the source in which a provided Visual is presented.

Removes a PresentationSource derived class instance from the list of known presentation sources.

Removes a handler for the SourceChanged event from the provided element.
RootChanged(Visual,Visual)

Provides notification that the root Visual has changed.

Events summary

ContentRendered

Occurs when content is rendered and ready for user interaction.

Constructors

  • PresentationSource()

    Provides initialization for base class values when called by the constructor of a derived class.

    protected PresentationSource ();

Properties

  • CompositionTarget

    Gets the visual target for the visuals being presented in the source.

    public System.Windows.Media.CompositionTarget CompositionTarget { get; }

    Property Value

    • CompositionTarget

      A visual target (instance of a CompositionTarget derived class).

    Remarks

    The return of this property relies on an implementation of GetCompositionTargetCore.

  • CurrentSources

    Returns a list of sources.

    public static System.Collections.IEnumerable CurrentSources { get; }

    Property Value

    • IEnumerable

      A list of weak references.

    Remarks

    The returned list supports an enumerator over a read-only, thread-safe copy of the list of sources as added with AddSource.

    The enumerator skips any dead weak references in the list.

  • IsDisposed

    When overridden in a derived class, gets a value that declares whether the object is disposed.

    public abstract bool IsDisposed { get; }

    Property Value

    • Boolean

      true if the object is disposed; otherwise, false.

  • RootVisual

    When overridden in a derived class, gets or sets the root visual being presented in the source.

    public abstract System.Windows.Media.Visual RootVisual { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Visual

      The root visual.

Methods

  • AddSource()

    Adds a PresentationSource derived class instance to the list of known presentation sources.

    protected void AddSource ();

    Remarks

    This method should be called by derived classes to indicate that they need to be tracked.

  • AddSourceChangedHandler(IInputElement,SourceChangedEventHandler)

    Adds a handler for the SourceChanged event to the provided element.

    public static void AddSourceChangedHandler (System.Windows.IInputElement element, System.Windows.SourceChangedEventHandler handler);

    Parameters

    • element
      IInputElement

      The element to add the handler to.

    • handler
      SourceChangedEventHandler

      The hander implementation to add.

    Remarks

    Despite what the syntax block for this event states, there is no legitimate Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) attached property usage. You should not attempt to add handlers in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), and handlers in code should only be placed on objects that serve as hosts for presentation (PresentationSource ) content. Such handlers should only be attached during object initialization, and should be explicitly removed in a Dispose method or equivalent object cleanup.

    Even though this is a routed event, there are special restrictions placed on this event that differ from normal routed event behavior, due to the relatively small number of elements in a typical application scenario that would concern themselves with handling this event.

    • You cannot use the UIElement or ContentElement AddHandler methods to add handlers. You must use AddSourceChangedHandler.

    • The C# += and -= event handler syntaxes, and related language specific handler syntaxes, are not supported, because the event itself is not exposed as public. Only the PresentationSource utility methods for adding and removing the handlers directly are supported.

    • Class handlers are not allowed. Specifically, you cannot call RegisterClassHandler against this event in a class constructor because although an identifier field exists for SourceChanged, the identifier is not public.

    • All registered handlers will receive the SourceChanged event even if one of the handlers attempts to mark the arguments as handled.

  • ClearContentRenderedListeners()

    Sets the list of listeners for the ContentRendered event to null.

    protected void ClearContentRenderedListeners ();
  • FromDependencyObject(DependencyObject)

    Returns the source in which a provided DependencyObject is presented.

    public static System.Windows.PresentationSource FromDependencyObject (System.Windows.DependencyObject dependencyObject);

    Parameters

    • dependencyObject
      DependencyObject

      The DependencyObject to find the source for.

    Returns

    • PresentationSource

      The PresentationSource in which the dependency object is being presented.

  • FromVisual(Visual)

    Returns the source in which a provided Visual is presented.

    public static System.Windows.PresentationSource FromVisual (System.Windows.Media.Visual visual);

    Parameters

    • visual
      Visual

      The Visual to find the source for.

    Returns

    • PresentationSource

      The PresentationSource in which the visual is being presented, or null if visual is disposed.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentNullException

      visual is null.

  • GetCompositionTargetCore()

    When overridden in a derived class, returns a visual target for the given source.

    protected abstract System.Windows.Media.CompositionTarget GetCompositionTargetCore ();

    Returns

    • CompositionTarget

      Returns a CompositionTarget that is target for rendering the visual.

  • RemoveSource()

    Removes a PresentationSource derived class instance from the list of known presentation sources.

    protected void RemoveSource ();
  • RemoveSourceChangedHandler(IInputElement,SourceChangedEventHandler)

    Removes a handler for the SourceChanged event from the provided element.

    public static void RemoveSourceChangedHandler (System.Windows.IInputElement e, System.Windows.SourceChangedEventHandler handler);

    Parameters

    • e
      IInputElement

      The element to remove the handler from.

    • handler
      SourceChangedEventHandler

      The handler implementation to remove.

    Remarks

    Even though this is a routed event, there are special restrictions placed on this event that differ from normal routed event behavior, due to the relatively small number of elements in a typical application scenario that would concern themselves with handling this event.

    • You cannot use the UIElement or ContentElement RemoveHandler methods to remove handlers. You must use RemoveSourceChangedHandler.

    • The C# += and -= event handler syntaxes, and other language specific handler syntaxes, are not supported, because the event itself is not exposed as public. Only the PresentationSource utility methods for adding and removing the handlers directly are supported.

  • RootChanged(Visual,Visual)

    Provides notification that the root Visual has changed.

    protected void RootChanged (System.Windows.Media.Visual oldRoot, System.Windows.Media.Visual newRoot);

    Parameters

    • oldRoot
      Visual

      The old root Visual.

    • newRoot
      Visual

      The new root Visual.

    Remarks

    Derived classes should call this method to indicate that their root Visual has changed.

    Calling this method causes two object lifetime events to be raised on the specified root visuals, if and only if those root visuals are FrameworkElement derived classes.

    • The old root visual will raise the Unloaded event, and will process its tree of elements downward, broadcasting this event to each child element.

    • The new root visual will raise the Loaded event, and will process its tree of elements downward, broadcasting this event to each child element.

Events

  • ContentRendered

    Occurs when content is rendered and ready for user interaction.

    public event EventHandler ContentRendered;
